the meat industry has harmful effects on the physical and mental health of its workers. eradication of this industry would reduce these harms.	3_1.3.1.4.1.3.	The meat industry has harmful effects on the physical and mental health of its workers. Eradication of this industry would reduce these harms.	pro	Eating meat has negative impacts on [worker safety](http://www.mdpi.com/1660-4601/13/2/197/pdf). Meatpacking workers are injured at a rate of 27.6 per 100 workers - double the average of all manufacturing industries.	Workers in other food producing industries do not fare any better than workers in the meat industry.	The meatpacking industry is [made particularly hazardous](https://www.hrw.org/news/2005/01/24/abuses-against-workers-taint-us-meat-and-poultry) due to a lack of training being provided to workers, close working quarters and insufficient safeguards.	This is a problem that should be solved through regulation of workplace conditions or temporary boycotts, not permanently ceasing to eat meat.	[Studies](http://www.news.com.au/national/slaughterhouse-workers-are-more-likely-to-be-violent-study-shows/news-story/f16165f66f38eb04a289eb8bd7f7f273) have shown that working in animal slaughterhouses leads to desensitisation to suffering and violence in general: abattoir workers have aggression levels comparable to those of incarcerated people, and towns with abattoirs have higher rates of domestic violence and violent crimes including murder and rape. This suggests not only that the meat industry harms worker psychology, but that it indirectly harms the wider human population as well.	This claim is a generalization. It is impossible to claim that the meat industry as a whole is harmful to its workers. Some companies may be harmful to its workers, but to apply this characterization to all companies in the meat industry is not logically sound.	Slaughterhouse workers often suffer from serious psychological damage due to the violence involved in their job.[ptsdjournal.com](http://www.ptsdjournal.com/posts/the-psychological-damage-of-slaughterhouse-work/)	Working on a fishing boat is a very hard and dangerous job and ranks [second](http://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2013/08/22/americas-10-deadliest-jobs-2/#3ea9405c5095) most deadliest in the US.	By this same logic, not eating meat involves being complicit in them losing their livelihood.	Poultry processing workers at big companies including Tyson, Pilgrim’s, Perdue and Sanderson Farms are denied [basic rights](https://upvoted.com/2016/05/27/we-wear-diapers-activists-behind-the-givethemabreak-campaign-reveal-the-horrific-conditions-of-poultry-workers/). They are not allowed to go to the toilet while working.

The meatpacking industry can be dangerous, but the solution for improving the safety of slaughterhouse workers is the strengthening of workplace safety rules, and increasing the monitoring of factories for safety violations.	Safety in the US meat industry has increased drastically since the early [1990s](https://www.meatinstitute.org/index.php?ht=a/GetDocumentAction/i/46343).	The source cited refers to poultry but in other branches of the meat industry safety standards are very high and injuries in the US decreased from [20% to 6%](https://www.meatinstitute.org/index.php?ht=a/GetDocumentAction/i/83419/) in 2012. The people who work in slaughterhouses likely do not care about killing animals, so employing them to do that is not mistreating them.
both [halal](https://special.worldofislam.info/index.php?page=food/halal_haram/2_conditions) \(islamic\) and [shechita](https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/kosher-slaughtering-an-introduction/) \(jewish\) laws surrounding the proper slaughter of meat would be likely to [prohibit](http://halalfoodauthority.com/faqs) mechanised slaughter due to the rules surrounding who is fit to slaughter and how the slaughtering must occur.	3_1.3.1.4.1.3.4.1.1.1.	Both [Halal](https://special.worldofislam.info/index.php?page=Food/halal_haram/2_conditions) \(Islamic\) and [Shechita](https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/kosher-slaughtering-an-introduction/) \(Jewish\) laws surrounding the proper slaughter of meat would be likely to [prohibit](http://halalfoodauthority.com/faqs) mechanised slaughter due to the rules surrounding who is fit to slaughter and how the slaughtering must occur.	pro	The Halal and Shechita presence on the Western meat market is [expanding](http://www.dialrel.eu/images/factsheet-market-uk.pdf); for example, Halal meat now comprises approximately 25% of the entire UK meat market, in comparison to 11% in 2001. Halal and Shechita methods therefore affect a significant \(and growing\) percentage of livestock destined for slaughter.
[studies](http://www.news.com.au/national/slaughterhouse-workers-are-more-likely-to-be-violent-study-shows/news-story/f16165f66f38eb04a289eb8bd7f7f273) have shown that working in animal slaughterhouses leads to desensitisation to suffering and violence in general: abattoir workers have aggression levels comparable to those of incarcerated people, and towns with abattoirs have higher rates of domestic violence and violent crimes including murder and rape. this suggests not only that the meat industry harms worker psychology, but that it indirectly harms the wider human population as well.	3_1.3.1.4.1.3.4.1.2.1.	[Studies](http://www.news.com.au/national/slaughterhouse-workers-are-more-likely-to-be-violent-study-shows/news-story/f16165f66f38eb04a289eb8bd7f7f273) have shown that working in animal slaughterhouses leads to desensitisation to suffering and violence in general: abattoir workers have aggression levels comparable to those of incarcerated people, and towns with abattoirs have higher rates of domestic violence and violent crimes including murder and rape. This suggests not only that the meat industry harms worker psychology, but that it indirectly harms the wider human population as well.	pro	It must also be considered that cause and effect could be reversed here. There could be many people with violent tendencies or desires who work in slaughterhouses in an attempt to give that violence a safer outlet.	Facilities regarded as undesirable to live near - such as abattoirs, power stations or prisons - are often built in locations that are already run-down and have a higher level of crime, thus these studies could say little about the true effect of slaughterhouses on local violent crime.
regardless of this, it is still possible that working in slaughterhouses could exacerbate pre-existing violent tendencies.	3_1.3.1.4.1.3.4.1.2.1.1.1.	Regardless of this, it is still possible that working in slaughterhouses could exacerbate pre-existing violent tendencies.	pro	One would have to avoid empathizing with the animals they must slaughter in order to avoid emotional pain when working in a slaughterhouse, which would likely involve avoiding or minimizing empathy entirely - which would in turn reduce one's empathy with other human beings and make one more likely to commit crimes or inflict violence against them.	Inflicting violence or wounds on animals is desensitizing to violence and wounds in general, as previously mentioned.

economists believe that [creative destruction](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/creativedestruction.asp) is pertinent for economic growth. 200 years ago [90% of the u.s. worforce](https://www.agclassroom.org/gan/timeline/farmers_land.htm) were farmers. if we hadn't let the farming jobs go, economic development would have been impossible and the rise of living standards would have been suppressed.	3_1.3.1.5. intensive livestock farming is economically bad for small farmers.	3_1.3.2.	Intensive livestock farming is economically bad for small farmers.	pro	As intensive farms are highly mechanized \(requiring little manual labor\) their introduction into rural areas tends to [reduce](http://thegreentimes.co.za/negative-impacts-of-factory-farming/) rural employment. In the U.S., for example, the number of farm workers has dropped 80% over the past 50 years.	The negative effects of mass-production on smaller retailers is true of most industries, it is not particular to livestock farming.	Intensive livestock farming is not the only option for small farmers. They can easily specialize in alternatives, such as organic livestock farming.	Some farms are only useful for livestock rearing. For example farms on areas of clay which cannot be ploughed. The farmers can only earn a living on small farms if they rear livestock intensively.

conflating the biological concept of harm \(meaning pain, distress, or the loss of quality of life\) with economics, is a major moral error that nullifies any argument with regards to "economic harm".	3_1.3.3.1.2. slavery was also once essential for economic concerns.	3_1.3.3.2.	Slavery was also once essential for economic concerns.	pro	"Economics" is simply the study of prices that arise from supply & demand. But morality in society determines what is allowed to be supplied or demanded. It is a major category error or a criminal fraud to pretend that because there is demand there must be supply, or vice versa. We don't think that way about offering children for sex abuse, for instance, or about nuclear fissile materials for bombs.

ceasing to produce meat will be necessary in order to meet the growing food needs of the world's population.	3_1.3.5.4.2.	Ceasing to produce meat will be necessary in order to meet the growing food needs of the world's population.	pro	Population growth is slowing down for last half century [ourworldindata.org](https://ourworldindata.org/world-population-growth)	The production of meat uses up agricultural land that should instead be used to grow crops.	Given current methods of agricultural production, the world will be unable to meet growing food demand. It is therefore urgent that we increase agricultural productivity by producing less meat.	There are various ways to exploit existing agricultural resources more efficiently to meet food demands.	The production of meat consumes disproportionately more resources than the production of crops.	There are over 7 billion people on the planet and we are not able to responsibly care for all of them. The correct choice of action is to lessen the population to manageable sizes. Ideally, the most intelligent course of action would be to lessen the population to the point where factory farms are not needed.	Moderation rather than prohibition should suffice; for any population level there is, mathematically speaking, an amount of meat that can be sustainably consumed \(e.g., each person eating meat twice per week might be sustainable for 7 billion people\).	[Meat is an unnecessary luxury food](https://makewealthhistory.org/2007/04/23/meat-is-a-luxury/) in a world of [food wastage](https://static5.businessinsider.com/image/56e1b879dd0895bb478b467d-960/ti_graphics_food-waste-regions-map.png) and [localized oversupply](https://assets.weforum.org/editor/KAPPoMvLpzHTC3IVCkz3T14jpvXwPAP7Z5eZubq6fr0.jpg).	We live in the 21st century and should progress out of the less civilized ways of living such as eating meat. The vegetarian movement will lead to more innovation as the meat industry ages and becomes obsolete. Humanity could advance ideas such as [feeding the future population](https://www.forbes.com/sites/ronaldholden/2017/11/04/its-called-vertical-farming-and-it-could-be-the-future-of-agriculture/#f787ccf11752) and [colonizing other planets](https://phys.org/news/2017-03-food-mars-earth-nasa-usu.html) when moving away from meat.	Just because something potentially becomes a problem in the future does not alone require it to stop today.	The land and water supply [is so low already](http://www.worldwatch.org/node/554) that soon we will have to find food sources that do not so heavily rely on agriculture.	Once someone eats a plant, they can use the [scraps to grow new food](https://www.diyncrafts.com/4732/repurpose/25-foods-can-re-grow-kitchen-scraps). Regenerating food takes pressure off the food system. The same cannot be said for meat.	Hunger and starvation worldwide [have been in decline even with a growing population until recently](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/global-hunger-rising-after-decade-decline-who-report/) and the recent increase is caused by war and global warming. Nothing indicates this growth to be a result of less meat production.	The growing food needs of the world's population can be met whether or not we stop meat production.

Current crop yields are [growing too slowly](https://hbr.org/2016/04/global-demand-for-food-is-rising-can-we-meet-it) to meet expected increases in food demand.	Climate change will [harm crop yields](https://hbr.org/2016/04/global-demand-for-food-is-rising-can-we-meet-it) by increasing global temperatures and extreme weather events.	There is a reasonable chance of large scientific innovations, like the [Green Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Revolution), drastically boosting our agricultural productivity without necessitating the removal of meat from our diets. from an ecological point of view, increased food availability for a given species, globally, results universally in an increase in species population.  population control can only verifiably and assuredly be effected using those same ecological principles of controlling or capping a food supply to sustain x population at equilibrium or possibly a gentle, gradual rate of decrease.	3_1.3.5.4.2.3.6.2.	From an ecological point of view, increased food availability for a given species, globally, results universally in an increase in species population.  Population control can only verifiably and assuredly be effected using those same ecological principles of controlling or capping a food supply to sustain x population at equilibrium or possibly a gentle, gradual rate of decrease.	pro

changing farming to feed a growing world population is only a never-ending treadmill if the population continues to grow. the vast majority of the world's population growth takes place in industrializing nations. population growth tends to level off in post-industrial nations and although these richer nations often import large amounts of luxury food, most of them are capable of producing all the food they need. as economic development becomes more uniform worldwide, population growth will slow.	3_1.3.5.4.2.6.6.3.	Changing farming to feed a growing world population is only a never-ending treadmill if the population continues to grow. The vast majority of the world's population growth takes place in industrializing nations. Population growth tends to level off in post-industrial nations and although these richer nations often import large amounts of luxury food, most of them are capable of producing all the food they need. As economic development becomes more uniform worldwide, population growth will slow.	pro

the practice and habit of moderation is much more difficult to follow successfully than simple abstention.	3_1.3.5.4.2.7.1.	The practice and habit of moderation is much more difficult to follow successfully than simple abstention.	pro	As long as meat eaters retain a taste for and willingness to consume meat, there is the danger that they will end up purchasing unethically produced meat.	Same is true for alcohol, still most people are not alcoholics and alcohol is not banned in most countries.	Moderation being tougher than abstention does not imply that the latter is unfeasible.	Moderation stems from discipline, which can be trained.	[This study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25453590) found that "\[Conscientious omnivores\] were less likely to perceive their diet as something that they absolutely needed to follow, reported violating their diet more, felt less guilty when doing so and that these differences could in part be traced to practical and psychological factors, making it more difficult to follow conscientious omnivorism."

The idea that eating meat is less civilized than not eating meat is a subjective value judgement, which is neither sufficiently justified here, nor widely accepted.	Evolutionary speaking, hominids only had access to meat after coming down from the trees, which means eating meat came after eating fruits and vegetables, and is therefore more civilized. Moreover, eating meat required the invention of weapons to hunt, and the discovery of fire, furthering the correlation between meat and civilization.

factory farming fosters poverty in the global south.	3_1.3.5.11.	Factory farming fosters poverty in the Global South.	pro	In [South Africa](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10806-015-9581-8) there are clear effects of meat consumption where local communities' major source of income is replaced by factory farming they cannot compete with. In developing countries, intensive livestock farming [obstructs](http://thegreentimes.co.za/negative-impacts-of-factory-farming/) poverty elimination by driving local farmers out of business.	Not all meat eaters consume meat from factory farming.	Meat factories create a very high demand for soybeans and corn which change the production patterns of the global south.	Much of the world's massive hunger problems could be solved by the reduction / elimination of meat-eating, as livestock pasture needs cut drastically into land which could otherwise be used to grow food.

much of the world's massive hunger problems could be solved by the reduction / elimination of meat-eating, as livestock pasture needs cut drastically into land which could otherwise be used to grow food.	3_1.3.5.11.6.	Much of the world's massive hunger problems could be solved by the reduction / elimination of meat-eating, as livestock pasture needs cut drastically into land which could otherwise be used to grow food.	pro	If everyone adopted a vegetarian diet, current food production would theoretically feed [10 billion people](http://www.uow.edu.au/~sharonb/STS300/limits/studies/articles/article2.html) \(56% more people than alive today\), more than the projected population for the year 2050.	According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN \(FAO\), 60% of the world’s agricultural land is used for grazing livestock and 1/4 of the world’s croplands is used for animal feed. In total, 2/3 of the world’s agricultural area and 1/3 of the total global land area is used for [maintaining livestock](https://www.ciwf.org.uk/includes/documents/cm_docs/2008/f/factory_farming_and_the_environment_1999.pdf).	[100 million people](http://www.vegsource.com/news/2009/09/how-to-win-an-argument-with-a-meat-eater.html) could be adequately fed using land freed if Americans reduced their intake of meat by 10%.
if everyone adopted a vegetarian diet, current food production would theoretically feed [10 billion people](http://www.uow.edu.au/~sharonb/sts300/limits/studies/articles/article2.html) \(56% more people than alive today\), more than the projected population for the year 2050.	3_1.3.5.11.6.1. in the short term, yes. in the long term not ceasing to waste land and continuing to emit massive amounts of unnecessary greenhouse gasses will incur devastating economic consequences.  beyond this, optimizing the use of water and ending subsidies for animal agriculture would encourage inevitable growth in other sectors, something which companies like best foods have been [compelled to accept](http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-hellmanns-vegan-mayonnaise-20160202-story.html) and are now making vegan mayonnaise after losing their lawsuit over eggless just mayo.	3_1.3.10. The meat substitutes industry can grow to replace the meat industry, taking jobs from the meat industry and creating new ones.	Meat and the meat industry would simply be replaced with the production of vegetarian foods, meaning the effects on the economy would be minimal.	We have examples of economic shift working already. In the dairy industry, for example. There are less people drinking milk now, which has caused the plant-milk and other non-dairy industries to flourish.

It is extremely difficult to transition from farming meat to farming normal agricultural products, and the transitionary period would cause drastic economic harms.	Other food production sectors would grow, meaning companies would require additional human capital to meet the new demand. As such, any jobs lost in the meat industry would simply appear in other food sectors.

The majority of humankind today do not share these same, natural practices.	Raising animals in confinement, deprived of sunlight, natural soil and freedom to move, is cruel and against their nature.	Consuming meat from organic livestock farming could help to mitigate these risks.	Meat requires [preservatives](http://www.foodauthority.nsw.gov.au/_Documents/industry/preservative_use_in_processed_meats.pdf) so it does not spoil.	Unnatural methods of farming could be easily curbed if industrial nations consumed less meat. Everyone being on a meatless diet is not necessary. So if consumption of dairy is acceptable so long as it is raised in a particular way, the consumption of meat is also acceptable so long as the meat is raised in that way. killing an animal inevitably and by definition ends its life. this could be considered to be an immoral act however it is carried out, especially as it robs the animal of whatever experiences, pleasure and/or enjoyment it may have got out of the rest of its life. conversely, keeping animals for non-meat products while treating them humanely and well would allow them to enjoy their full natural lives while producing useful products.	3_1.4.1.7.2.7.1.1.	Killing an animal inevitably and by definition ends its life. This could be considered to be an immoral act however it is carried out, especially as it robs the animal of whatever experiences, pleasure and/or enjoyment it may have got out of the rest of its life. Conversely, keeping animals for non-meat products while treating them humanely and well would allow them to enjoy their full natural lives while producing useful products.	pro	
unfortunately, dairy cows only produce milk once pregnant \(and shortly thereafter\). if a calf is male, it is often \(even on small farms\) killed, as it is more expensive to raise it. or, it is sold to veal farming, which is inherently cruel \(i can explain further if needed\). if a calf is female, it's stolen away from the mother and not allowed to drink any of the milk, because the milk must be sold for money for humans. this process, even without overt visible cruelty, is very, very cruel.	3_1.4.1.7.2.7.1.2. In fact, human evolution allowed for and selected for milk drinking past weaning and of another animal as in several human populations mutations arose and [naturally selected for us to drink milk](https://www.nature.com/articles/5201297) of another mammal past weaning.

A peaceful life on a farm is plausibly preferable to a life in the wild.	pro	Wild animals almost invariably suffer more than domesticated animals properly farmed. There is no end to a wild life that is not brutal. There is no reason to assume that a natural lifestyle is essential \(healthwise or morally\), as there are plenty of reasons for humans to follow an "unnatural" lifestyle.	pro	Thanks to un-natural means such as modern medicine the lifespan of humans has [increased tremendously](https://www.nia.nih.gov/sites/default/files/global_health_and_aging.pdf). The lifespan of our closest primate relatives, who are presumed to live a natural lifestyle, is [merely half](http://bigthink.com/videos/natures-calling-how-long-should-humans-live) of ours.	Only through the development and wide-spread use of medical inventions, such as vaccinations, was it possible to protect humans from or even eradicate various naturally occurring infectious diseases.	A lifestyle that takes into account the natural requirements and limitations of the human body is certainly more healthy than one ignoring them.	A more natural lifestyle causes fewer interruptions to the functioning of our body, such as caused by additives to beauty articles like [deodorant](http://www.realpurity.com/blog/top-4-benefits-of-natural-living/).	There is hardly anyone living a natural life in its complete sense. Thus it cannot be essential. only through the development and wide-spread use of medical inventions, such as vaccinations, was it possible to protect humans from or even eradicate various naturally occurring infectious diseases.	3_1.4.1.7.4.3.2.	Only through the development and wide-spread use of medical inventions, such as vaccinations, was it possible to protect humans from or even eradicate various naturally occurring infectious diseases.	pro	Until the Mid-20th century it was natural for millions to suffer from smallpox, many of whose victims went blind and died. The disease was responsible for [300 to 500 million deaths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smallpox) in the 20th century - but was [successfully eradicated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smallpox#Eradication) through the use of vaccinations by 1980.	Vaccines are based on parts of the bacteria or the virus that make up a disease. In this sense, the working ingredient of vaccines [is actually natural](http://www.chop.edu/centers-programs/vaccine-education-center/vaccine-safety/immune-system-and-health#.V2Mvbfl96Hs).	The wide-spread use of un-natural vaccines was able to decrease the worldwide cases of Polio [by 99%](http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs114/en/) since 1988: From 305.000 to 74.	Vaccines work through a [natural mechanism](http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/think-vaccines) and merely provoke the human immune system to produce its own, perfectly natural anti-bodies to viruses and diseases.
until the mid-20th century it was natural for millions to suffer from smallpox, many of whose victims went blind and died. the disease was responsible for [300 to 500 million deaths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/smallpox) in the 20th century - but was [successfully eradicated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/smallpox#eradication) through the use of vaccinations by 1980.	3_1.4.1.7.4.3.2.1. Therefore the "path" they allegedly chose is determined as well and not a product of their consciousness.	Consciousness is merely a result of [physical material interactions](http://www.eagleman.com/incognito). The brain is a system whose operation is governed by the laws of chemistry and physics, thus all of our thoughts, emotions and decisions are produced by natural reactions and not, as we like to think, by individual decision.

just like other conceptions of what is natural, the idea of eating meat as being natural is socially constructed and subject to change.	3_1.4.3.	Just like other conceptions of what is natural, the idea of eating meat as being natural is socially constructed and subject to change.	pro	That ancestors ate meat is an evidence proven fact and no social construction.	[A study](http://ww.w.humanecologyreview.org/pastissues/her101/101gossardyork.pdf) looking into the reasons for individuals' 'Environmentally Significant Consumption' found that social structural factors, macro-economic structure and psychological factors can all offer an explanation of the meat \(or lack thereof\) consumption patterns of individuals.	Something is natural if it occurs in nature, without modern human interference. Its definition never changed and is certainly not a human construct.	The digestion of meat and the absorption of its many nutrients, are not social constructs.	The consideration of the superiority of any diet, including a meatless one, is equally a construct.	Humans have abandoned or modified behaviours that were once considered natural.

humans have abandoned or modified behaviours that were once considered natural.	3_1.4.3.6. It was once deemed natural to eat with one's bare hands, but humans went on to invent utensils to eat instead.	There are many things that are currently or were once considered "natural" that humans have ceased doing or have put limits on. For example, sex is natural yet there are obvious legal and cultural restrictions surrounding who, when, where, and how we can have sex. It is in human nature to hurt and kill each other, yet it is is illegal and immoral to do so in 99% of these instances. Wearing clothing is not natural, yet we do so. Bottom line: Culture, nature, and morality are often in conflict.

this argument commits the [fallacy of equivocation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/equivocation). by not explicitly defining "self-awareness", the ambiguity surrounding the term allows for equivocation on the ideas of self-awareness and consciousness. the argument may thus suggest there is no "objective boundary" between plant and animal life in this regard, while "self-awareness", properly defined, would preclude such an argument based on our knowledge of the neural substrates of [introspection/self-referential thought](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s1364661313002118).	3_1.4.6.1.	This argument commits the [fallacy of equivocation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equivocation). By not explicitly defining "self-awareness", the ambiguity surrounding the term allows for equivocation on the ideas of self-awareness and consciousness. The argument may thus suggest there is no "objective boundary" between plant and animal life in this regard, while "Self-awareness", properly defined, would preclude such an argument based on our knowledge of the neural substrates of [introspection/self-referential thought](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1364661313002118).	pro

just because something comes naturally to humans, it does not mean it is the correct decision to do it.	3_1.4.8.	Just because something comes naturally to humans, it does not mean it is the correct decision to do it.	pro	If this were a valid argument, it could equally be made in favour of genocide, rape, torture, destruction of ecosystems, slavery, suppression, etc. \(see other great apes, our closest relatives, for inspiration\).	The fact that eating meat is natural or inherent to human culture does not imply that we ought to eat it. According to Hume, it is a fallacy to make claims about what [ought to be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Is%E2%80%93ought_problem) \("we ought to eat meat"\) on the basis of statements about what is \("it is natural to eat meat"\).	Historically, many behaviours could have been considered "a central part of human nature and thus inherent to humankind" yet are now considered abhorrent and forbidden, such as murder for resources on an individual level.
if this were a valid argument, it could equally be made in favour of genocide, rape, torture, destruction of ecosystems, slavery, suppression, etc. \(see other great apes, our closest relatives, for inspiration\).	3_1.4.8.1. This is a fallacy.
the fact that eating meat is natural or inherent to human culture does not imply that we ought to eat it. according to hume, it is a fallacy to make claims about what [ought to be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/is%e2%80%93ought_problem) \("we ought to eat meat"\) on the basis of statements about what is \("it is natural to eat meat"\).	3_1.4.8.2.	The fact that eating meat is natural or inherent to human culture does not imply that we ought to eat it. According to Hume, it is a fallacy to make claims about what [ought to be](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Is%E2%80%93ought_problem) \("we ought to eat meat"\) on the basis of statements about what is \("it is natural to eat meat"\).	pro	'What is' is a better indicator than philosophical thoughts on 'what ought to be' because it has shown its applicability.	Humans ought to do what it is in their nature to do.	Additionally, we should seek to get the relationship between what is *normative* and what is *normal* the right way around. The normative should dictate what is normal. Just because an act is normal does not in and of itself signify that the act is therefore good, just, beautiful, or useful.	One philosopher should not dictate what the entirety of human existence inherently desires.	The cultural basis for meat consumption originated in hunter gatherer times. We no longer live in hunter gather societies and therefore dietary custom is an antiquated justification for meat consumption. Hunter gatherer meat consumption is more justified than agrarian meat consumption because meat was a scarcity that had to be earned; consequently it was the highlight of the meal. The amount of meat consumed is unnatural and is therefore at odds with the foundation of this cultural argument.
every progressive change throughout history involved people collectively taking action to change "what is" in favor of their view of "what ought to be". so if we look at "what is", we discover that it *is* the case that there exists an extensive proven track record of successful cases where "what ought to be" has led to positive cultural change that we value today. so by this point's own reasoning, we should therefore take "what ought to be" seriously.	3_1.4.8.2.1.1.	Every progressive change throughout history involved people collectively taking action to change "what is" in favor of their view of "what ought to be". So if we look at "what is", we discover that it *is* the case that there exists an extensive proven track record of successful cases where "what ought to be" has led to positive cultural change that we value today. So by this point's own reasoning, we should therefore take "what ought to be" seriously.	pro

the cultural basis for meat consumption originated in hunter gatherer times. we no longer live in hunter gather societies and therefore dietary custom is an antiquated justification for meat consumption. hunter gatherer meat consumption is more justified than agrarian meat consumption because meat was a scarcity that had to be earned; consequently it was the highlight of the meal. the amount of meat consumed is unnatural and is therefore at odds with the foundation of this cultural argument.	3_1.4.8.2.5. the quality of "tasty" is a fluid concept based more on the idea of [appetitive and aversive taste stimuli](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/two-great-tastes-not-great-together/). indeed, while appetitive tastants \(e.g. sugar, salt, umami\) signal calorie-rich foods the organism should consume, high concentrations of these [tastants can actually become aversive](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature11905).	3_1.4.13.4.	The quality of "tasty" is a fluid concept based more on the idea of [appetitive and aversive taste stimuli](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/two-great-tastes-not-great-together/). Indeed, while appetitive tastants \(e.g. sugar, salt, umami\) signal calorie-rich foods the organism should consume, high concentrations of these [tastants can actually become aversive](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature11905).	pro

vegetarianism is a greater part of our genetic heritage than meat-eating. rationale: apes spent more time evolving during the miocene than the early humans \(which is a sub-group of the apes\) did later during the pleistocene.  all other apes are almost vegetarians.\([livescience.com](https://www.livescience.com/51017-ape-facts.html),[newscientist.com](https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn3966-ape-diet-lowers-bad-cholesterol-levels/)\)	3_1.4.19.3.	Vegetarianism is a greater part of our genetic heritage than meat-eating. Rationale: Apes spent more time evolving during the Miocene than the early humans \(which is a sub-group of the apes\) did later during the Pleistocene.  All other apes are almost vegetarians.\([livescience.com](https://www.livescience.com/51017-ape-facts.html),[newscientist.com](https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn3966-ape-diet-lowers-bad-cholesterol-levels/)\)	pro	
it's easier to gather a plant than to hunt an animal. therefore our ancestors were more gatherers than hunters.	3_1.4.19.4.	It's easier to gather a plant than to hunt an animal. Therefore our ancestors were more gatherers than hunters.	pro	It might be easier to gather a plant, but it is not easier to plant than to hunt. Taking into consideration that this involves a nuanced understanding of farming, having to plant, water, cultivate and wait, planting and eating only plants is not an option if you are starving. Hunting could potentially take minutes/hours, whereas farming involves constant attention over months.	From experience in the bush, it is easier and more efficient to get your daily needs for nutrition by hunting and eating animals than it is by gathering plants. Therefore I would argue that our ancestors met their caloric needs primarily through animal consumption.
exact numbers of teeth are not relevant, as evolution does not "plan ahead" in this manner or deliberately create specific ratios, rather creates or further emphasizes traits which prove useful. humans would develop exactly as many canines \(and molars\) as they needed at the time, so the exact numbers or ratios do not prove what is described here, as it is possible that having more molars is more beneficial in ways that having more canines is not. \(also, molars are still used to chew meat.\)	3_1.4.19.6.1.1.	Exact numbers of teeth are not relevant, as evolution does not "plan ahead" in this manner or deliberately create specific ratios, rather creates or further emphasizes traits which prove useful. Humans would develop exactly as many canines \(and molars\) as they needed at the time, so the exact numbers or ratios do not prove what is described here, as it is possible that having more molars is more beneficial in ways that having more canines is not. \(Also, molars are still used to chew meat.\)	pro

whilst we may have been hunter-gatherers in the past it does not mean we should continue to be. continuing to be hunter-gatherers on the basis that we were known as hunter-gatherers is an [appeal to tradition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/appeal_to_tradition)	3_1.4.19.10. Continuing to be hunter-gatherers on the basis that we were known as hunter-gatherers is an [Appeal to Tradition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appeal_to_tradition)	pro	A specific mode of nutrition is no tradition; otherwise, all living beings have traditions. Rather, it is a naturally \(evolutionary\) developed way of behavior. Therefore, this is no appeal to tradition but an appeal to our nature.

Therefore animals only know one right: the right of the strongest.
by this logic babies, little children as well as severely mentally disabled people cannot be possessors of rights either. but that would be wrong.	3_1.5.1.2.2.	By this logic babies, little children as well as severely mentally disabled people cannot be possessors of rights either. But that would be wrong.	pro	Infants and disabled humans are participants in the human moral community, and so they possess rights.	Animals do not have the potential of ever being part of the human community, whereas the mentally disabled and little children do.	If conceptualisation of morality was a precondition to 'exist within our moral community' and to have the right to live and not be tortured and slaughtered, it would become permissible to harm pets, members of different moral communities \(different cultures\), people in a coma, with dementia and many others	Sentience is not moral justification for enslaving other beings across species-lines, any more than it is moral justification for enslaving ones own species who biologically lack cognitive abilities due to medical disorder. What about the taxonomy of a being permits otherwise morally egregious behavior?	Babies, little children, and the mentally disabled do have substantially fewer rights than healthy adults. At the extreme end, a fetus can be aborted and people with extreme brain damage can be taken off life-support without their consent. Similarly, the animals should be provided a limited set of rights \(which they are, though I'll admit it should be expanded\) but I don't see anything substantially worse about a cow being slaughtered at a young age than dying of a disease at old age.

animals possess certain rights.	3_1.5.1.3.2.	Animals possess certain rights.	pro	In 2008, a committee of Spain's national legislature became the first to vote for a resolution [to extend limited rights](http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/13/weekinreview/13mcneil.html?_r=2&ref=science&oref=slogin) to nonhuman primates.	In 1999, [Public Law 106-152](http://www.pet-abuse.com/pages/animal_cruelty/crush_videos.php#ixzz2C6yKSljR%3E) \(Title 18, Section 48\) was put into action in the US. This law makes it a felony to create, sell, or possess videos showing animal cruelty with the intention of profiting financially from them.	In 2015, the New Zealand Parliament unanimously passed the [Animal Welfare Amendment Act](http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/new-zealand-animal-welfare-legislation-recognizes-animals-as-sentient-bans-cosmetic-testing/) \(No. 2\) 2015, which includes an amendment to the long title of the principal legislation, the Animal Welfare Act 1999, in order to specifically recognize animals as sentient.

animal rights theory claims, in its most part, negative rights for animals, i.e.: the right not to suffer, not to die, not to \(...\). some non-paradigmatic humans may have no positive rights, but they still have their negative rights guaranteed.	3_1.5.1.3.6. Some non-paradigmatic humans may have no positive rights, but they still have their negative rights guaranteed.	pro	Negative rights for humans arise from an agreement not to violate the negative rights of others. We have created laws and customs, "suspended" the law of nature in order to ensure peaceful coexistence with each other. plenty of natural species do benefit from cooperation and peaceful coexistence outside of their own species. symbiosis is a widely acknowledged facet of nature. furthermore, there is no reason to believe humans could not use their reason to further benefit from "unnatural" and "artificial" symbiosis, nor is there any reason to suggest humans should not altruistically use such "artificial" symbiosis to improve the lives of other animals, as long as any downsides are appropriately managed.	3_1.5.2.1.1.1. bringing an entity into existence does not mean that you have the ability to use that entity for whatever purpose you want.	3_1.5.4.1.2.	Bringing an entity into existence does not mean that you have the ability to use that entity for whatever purpose you want.	pro	All humans are also born due to the actions and decisions of their parents. It is not subsequently moral to treat them however you wish to meet your own ends. Once a living being is alive, they should be subject to the same standard of morality that empathy drives us to apply to human children. Empathy naturally decreases the further from our species an animal gets, but we have empathy for them regardless.	That's like saying it's a parent's right to be abusive by virtue of causing their child's birth. The basic rights of any living creature are not affected by the circumstances of its birth.	This renders the concept of birth as giving claim to another life as being property to do with as one pleases. Ownership/property mentality as a form of colonialism was used for generations to rationalize the abuse of animals, children, women, other races, religions, under the concept that another is property to the person, group or country who feeds, employs or "owns" it, putting that life under their control. We have since implemented laws to counter abuses perpetrated under this philosophy.

human rights only emerged through generations of human individuals failing to seek or achieve those rights. rights are achieved by ending oppression. as exemplified by historical freedom stories, the worthiness of animals for rights is the matter under examination when weighing the morality of killing them for food.	3_1.5.4.3.1.1.	Human rights only emerged through generations of human individuals failing to seek or achieve those rights. Rights are achieved by ending oppression. As exemplified by historical freedom stories, the worthiness of animals for rights is the matter under examination when weighing the morality of killing them for food.	pro	The mere fact that human rights were created through the removal of oppression does not mean that animals are analogous to previously oppressed groups of humans.
animals don't lack rights, and even if they did, they shouldn't. we should consider cruelty to animals immoral for the same reason we consider cruelty to humans immoral. it is an affront to the empathy we share with living beings.	3_1.5.4.3.1.2.	Animals don't lack rights, and even if they did, they shouldn't. We should consider cruelty to animals immoral for the same reason we consider cruelty to humans immoral. It is an affront to the empathy we share with living beings.	pro

"unbalanced in value" is dubious. by what objective measure of value are you using? you are basing the value of a life on their potential to achieve some human-centric measure of worth. a feral human left in the wild, or a mentally handicapped child, is of equal value to a penned sheep then.	3_1.5.4.3.2.3. A feral human left in the wild, or a mentally handicapped child, is of equal value to a penned sheep then.	pro	
who is to argue when anthropomorphising is or isn't wrong? blacks were enslaved because they were just brutes. then one day we anthropomorphised them. voila, suddenly rights are bestowed.	3_1.5.4.3.2.4.	Who is to argue when anthropomorphising is or isn't wrong? Blacks were enslaved because they were just brutes. Then one day we anthropomorphised them. Voila, suddenly rights are bestowed.	pro	Many indigenous peoples had broad arts, culture, and tradition, and sophisticated societies involving living in harmony with the land, other animals, and each other. Often this was a reasoned process developed and passed down through generations \(much like our own technology!\), not merely instinctual. Deliberately moderating your group's consumption in the name of sustainability, for instance, is hardly a "brutish" trait or culture. It is not "anthropomorphizing" to recognize genuine virtues.

In fact most survive to experience a natural cause of death.	pro	Every animal is consumed by a scavenger of some kind though, some even microbial in nature, as originally stated. Therefore there is little difference between humans eating animals, and other wild life. If it is not immoral for a predator to eat prey, then it is not immoral for humans to eat animals as well.

an animal that isn't born can't prefer to be born at all as they don't exist. an animal that exists currently doesn't want to die prematurely \(they actively avoid pain\). since we know they don't want to die \(avoid pain\) it is ethical not to harm them. if we create animals to kill \(harm\) we are acting unethically.	3_1.5.4.4.1. Since we know they don't want to die \(avoid pain\) it is ethical not to harm them. If we create animals to kill \(harm\) we are acting unethically.	pro

a social contract implies a mutual benefit. the relationship between domesticated animals and their human captures is not a mutually beneficial relationship. animals raised for slaughter are artificially selected for traits that humans value, which inhibit the animal's ability to survive in the wild. each of our domesticated species suffers from various illnesses and conditions that are a direct result of captivity and human exploitation.	3_1.5.4.7.1.	A social contract implies a mutual benefit. The relationship between domesticated animals and their human captures is not a mutually beneficial relationship. Animals raised for slaughter are artificially selected for traits that humans value, which inhibit the animal's ability to survive in the wild. Each of our domesticated species suffers from various illnesses and conditions that are a direct result of captivity and human exploitation.	pro

animals should have rights because they are sentient beings.	3_1.5.5.	Animals should have rights because they are sentient beings.	pro	Animals do not conceive of pain and death the same way humans do.	Because animals feel, they should be treated according to [utilitarian ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism), which advocates maximising pleasure and minimising suffering for all sentient beings.	Animals from a wide range of species have been shown to experience [emotions](https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions/201306/universal-declaration-animal-sentience-no-pretending) including happiness, grief, empathy and jealousy.	Sentience is not a sufficient condition for having rights. For example, ants are sentient, but it would be unreasonable to say that they have a right to life.	We should grant rights to all sentient beings because there is no consistent way of differentiating between humans \(who have rights\) and other sentient beings.	Animals are sentient, but not rational, therefore cannot predict suffering or conceive their fates in slaughter houses. Rights emerge from the prediction of suffering.	Animals are not as self aware as humans, so they would not be aware of their coming death until it's already happened. Especially as the methods of doing so are quick and painless.	Non-human animals, just like humans, are sencient and have a conscience. The conscience issue has been stated by '[The Cambridge Declaration on Consciousness](http://fcmconference.org/img/CambridgeDeclarationOnConsciousness.pdf)' issued by a prominent international group of cognitive neuroscientists, neuropharmacologists, neurophysiologists, neuroanatomists and computational neuroscientists gathered at The University of Cambridge.	If we accept the fact that killing humans is wrong, as we are sentient beings, so is the killing of animals wrong as well. It is a clear fact that animals feel pain, join, etc. Some of them live among us as fellows, helpers...so if that's the reality for some that should be for all of them. It would be fair that way.
as kant would point: you cannot access the "being" of the things, so you cannot feel the pain of the other animal. you can only see the phenomena. looking to the phenomena of a screaming dog, you can't tell if he is living "existential pain", but you can surely tell that he is having a bad time.	3_1.5.5.1.1.1.	As Kant would point: You cannot access the "being" of the things, so you cannot feel the pain of the other animal. You can only see the phenomena. Looking to the phenomena of a screaming dog, you can't tell if he is living "existential pain", but you can surely tell that he is having a bad time.	pro	
in order to feel pain, one must have some kind of consciousness, because he knows how to distinguish himself from the world. its like: "it's me who feel pain", and not this stone or this other dog. one must have some kind of conscience of his body in-the-world, in order to feel pain.	3_1.5.5.1.2.	In order to feel pain, one must have some kind of consciousness, because he knows how to distinguish himself from the world. Its like: "It's me who feel pain", and not this stone or this other dog. One must have some kind of conscience of his body in-the-world, in order to feel pain.	pro	If an entity feels pain, then it necessarily has a sense of self, because it can distinguish itself from the world. Self-awareness is, really, necessary to have a conscious feeling of pain, so, something feels pain, then it must be self-aware in some way. The difference between the 'pain' state of mind in different animals cannot be proven, since all of them show us the same phenomena: if, e.g., the ache is in their feet, they scream, stop walking or start limping, etc.
if an entity feels pain, then it necessarily has a sense of self, because it can distinguish itself from the world. self-awareness is, really, necessary to have a conscious feeling of pain, so, something feels pain, then it must be self-aware in some way. the difference between the 'pain' state of mind in different animals cannot be proven, since all of them show us the same phenomena: if, e.g., the ache is in their feet, they scream, stop walking or start limping, etc.	3_1.5.5.1.2.1.	If an entity feels pain, then it necessarily has a sense of self, because it can distinguish itself from the world. Self-awareness is, really, necessary to have a conscious feeling of pain, so, something feels pain, then it must be self-aware in some way. The difference between the 'pain' state of mind in different animals cannot be proven, since all of them show us the same phenomena: if, e.g., the ache is in their feet, they scream, stop walking or start limping, etc.	pro

because animals feel, they should be treated according to [utilitarian ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/utilitarianism), which advocates maximising pleasure and minimising suffering for all sentient beings.	3_1.5.5.2.	Because animals feel, they should be treated according to [utilitarian ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism), which advocates maximising pleasure and minimising suffering for all sentient beings.	pro	The pleasure of a human is worth more than the life of an animal because it is scarcer. Thus, utilitarian ethics suggest that humans should keep eating meat.	Humans are capable of culture, innovation, and the sublimation of instinct in order to act in an ethical manner. Animals are not, thus they are unequal to humans on a moral level.	Act utilitarian [Peter Singer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_Liberation_%28book%29) argues that the Basic Principle of Equality should be extended to nonhuman animals and that it would demand us to equally consider the interests of animals.	Billions of animals are brutalized and tortured on factory farms every year. Since the only pleasure humans get from eating meat is gustatory pleasure, it is doubtful that the pain and suffering that these animals experience can ever be justified according to utilitarian principles.	Utilitarian ethics is not only a disputed way of thinking, but is very difficult to implement \(for instance, what is the appropriate time span of pain/pleasure that we are computing?\), especially in nature, which does not care about utilitarianism.	We are beginning to find evidence that [plants feel as well.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CrrSAc-vjG4) If plants and animals both feel, we cannot afford to treat them both with utilitarian ethics, we have to eat something! Animals are not more deserving of care than plants. No matter what we do, we'll be making an ethical compromise and killing a living, feeling being.	Many animals are incapable of feeling pain. Depending on the definition of sentient this may not be able to be applied to meat from any source in general.	Farm [animals feel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_consciousness) pleasure and sadness, excitement and resentment, depression, fear and pain. They are [sentient](http://www.livescience.com/39481-time-to-declare-animal-sentience.html) and intelligent beings, thus utilitarianism can be applied to them. \([psychologytoday.com](https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions/201306/universal-declaration-animal-sentience-no-pretending)\)	A pleasure maximizing ethical paradigm might just as easily justify breeding livestock for food, raising them in a way that maximizes their happiness, and killing them in the most humane manner possible. By bringing a life into this world you are increasing total happiness and satisfying the tastes/preferences of humans who desire meat as food.	The argument has been made that plants are [equally sentient and intelligent](http://www.theguardian.com/environment/radical-conservation/2015/aug/04/plants-intelligent-sentient-book-brilliant-green-internet), even though not in the same sense as humans and animals are. By the same logic, utilitarian ethics would forbid the killing of plants.

it is sensible and more feasible to start taking action in areas that we are directly involved with and responsible for. unlike the suffering of farm animals, the [suffering](http://foundational-research.org/the-importance-of-wild-animal-suffering/) of wild animals is in large part not related to human actions, but to natural predators, diseases, harsh natural habitats, naturally short life-spans, more offspring than can be fed, etc.	3_1.5.5.2.1.2.1.2. Not necessarily as much as we ingest right now, but it certainly is not wrong.

for any supposed capacity that humans possess and animals lack, and in virtue of which humans but not animals are taken to have rights, some humans will lack that capacity and some animals may possess that capacity. for instance, humans generally have the ability to reason, while most animals lack this capacity. but this cannot be the basis on which humans have and animals lack rights, because certain humans, including young infants, lack the ability to reason and certain animals may have it.	3_1.5.5.2.2.4. act utilitarian [peter singer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/animal_liberation_%28book%29) argues that the basic principle of equality should be extended to nonhuman animals and that it would demand us to equally consider the interests of animals.	3_1.5.5.2.3.	Act utilitarian [Peter Singer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_Liberation_%28book%29) argues that the Basic Principle of Equality should be extended to nonhuman animals and that it would demand us to equally consider the interests of animals.	pro	Singer bases his argument on the presence of interests. If a being has interests, these have to be taken into account. Yet this would make eating plants as immoral as eating animals as they obviously have interests, for example in survival and reproduction. Singer's argument therefore suffers [from arbitrary delineations](http://www.abc.net.au/religion/articles/2014/08/05/4061202.htm).

Eating meat is not. Thus, there is a difference in the logic applied.	pro	It is possible to only eat meat for one year. As a study from 1930 illustrates '[nothing much](https://swizec.com/blog/week-17-what-happens-when-you-only-eat-meat-for-a-year/swizec/6534)' happens.	[Inuit](http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2011-04/fyi-what-would-happen-if-i-ate-nothing-meat) ate mainly meat and hardly any plants and survived.	Crops provide us with important [minerals](http://www.eatbalanced.com/why-eat-balanced/why-do-we-need-minerals/) that are essential for a variety of bodily functions.	Dietary [fibre](http://www.eatbalanced.com/why-eat-balanced/why-do-we-need-fibre/) is present in all plant foods – fruits, vegetables and grains – but not in animal foods. Without fibre we cannot survive and therefore need to eat plants. dietary [fibre](http://www.eatbalanced.com/why-eat-balanced/why-do-we-need-fibre/) is present in all plant foods – fruits, vegetables and grains – but not in animal foods. without fibre we cannot survive and therefore need to eat plants.	3_1.5.5.2.10.1.4.	Dietary [fibre](http://www.eatbalanced.com/why-eat-balanced/why-do-we-need-fibre/) is present in all plant foods – fruits, vegetables and grains – but not in animal foods. Without fibre we cannot survive and therefore need to eat plants.	pro	Fibre smooths out digestion and absorption of glucose and fats in the small intestine.	Fibre provides fuel for the healthful or “good” bacteria in our large intestine which in turn benefit us by making vitamin B12, and by releasing volatile fatty acids from the dietary fibre which are important for the health of our colon.	Fibre speeds up transit though the intestines to remove waste and toxins from our body.

as noted in the linked article, plants are able to survive losing a large portion of their biomass - and many produce fruiting bodies deliberately intended for consumption by animals - whereas harvesting an animal for meat kills it 100% of the time. it is more possible to ethically harvest \(some\) plants than animals.	3_1.5.5.2.10.2. It is more possible to ethically harvest \(some\) plants than animals.	pro	
farming animals for meat requires either farming plants for their food, or allowing them to graze in deliberately altered semi-natural environments. therefore, farming meat produces a greater utilitarian loss than farming plants, as farming plants only harms and kills plants directly, while farming meat harms and kills both plants and the animals.	3_1.5.5.2.10.3.	Farming animals for meat requires either farming plants for their food, or allowing them to graze in deliberately altered semi-natural environments. Therefore, farming meat produces a greater utilitarian loss than farming plants, as farming plants only harms and kills plants directly, while farming meat harms and kills both plants and the animals.	pro	
animals from a wide range of species have been shown to experience [emotions](https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions/201306/universal-declaration-animal-sentience-no-pretending) including happiness, grief, empathy and jealousy.	3_1.5.5.3.	Animals from a wide range of species have been shown to experience [emotions](https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions/201306/universal-declaration-animal-sentience-no-pretending) including happiness, grief, empathy and jealousy.	pro	Animals' sentience is [instantaneous](https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/02/150225-dogs-memories-animals-chimpanzees-science-mind-psychology/) and ephemeral, they are not capable of long term predictions, therefore not suffering in anticipation to existential angst in events such as death.
sentience is a matter of degree. farm animals are sufficiently sentient that we should grant them rights.	3_1.5.5.4.1.	Sentience is a matter of degree. Farm animals are sufficiently sentient that we should grant them rights.	pro	
it would, however, be reasonable to say we should not interfere with them without reason to, thereby implying certain rights to "life" and non-interference.	3_1.5.5.4.2. we should grant rights to all sentient beings because there is no consistent way of differentiating between humans \(who have rights\) and other sentient beings.	3_1.5.5.5.	We should grant rights to all sentient beings because there is no consistent way of differentiating between humans \(who have rights\) and other sentient beings.	pro	There is no inherent difference between animals and humans; to insist otherwise is [speciesism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speciesism), the act of discriminating against a being on the basis of their species.	Humans are participants in a human moral community; this is sufficient to distinguish them from animals.	Since there is no way of knowing how truly 'sentient' or 'non-sentient' something is, drawing the line somewhere on that spectrum between what is and is not sentient would be far more arbitrary than if we just drew the line between human and non-human life.	The ability to paint some lives as inferior despite the fact that intelligence is relative also allows for human suffering, and assuring the basic protection of all conscious lives would be a step towards a more conscientious global community.	Humans understand that we feel pain and that other beings can feel pain, including animals. Although they may not understand our pain, we understand theirs, which gives our actions towards them moral weight. If killing is wrong than killing animals is wrong.

[animals demonstrate causal reasoning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/causal_reasoning#causal_reasoning_in_non-human_animals) in the same way humans do. for example pavlov's dogs demonstrate animals can learn about cause and effect, [some animals use causal reasoning to make tools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/tool_use_by_animals)and [crows can reason about hidden causal agents in a way which was incorrectly believed to be unique to humans.](http://www.pnas.org/content/109/40/16389)	3_1.5.5.6.2. eating meat violates animals' right to life.	3_1.5.6.	Eating meat violates animals' right to life.	pro	Unlike wild animals, farmed animals are born explicitly due to human action. While we may have a duty to ensure that their lives are not unnecessarily cruel, it is not immoral to kill them for our own ends given they would not have existed otherwise.	Animals desire to continue existing. This is sufficient to grant them a right to life.	With that logic, eating plants, fruits or vegetables also violates their right to life. There is nothing wrong with the occurrence of natural selection and the circle of life.	Animals have no rights because they have no obligations.	Nature doesn't give animals a right to life. It kills them cruelly and in great numbers.
animals desire to continue existing. this is sufficient to grant them a right to life.	3_1.5.6.2.	Animals desire to continue existing. This is sufficient to grant them a right to life.	pro	Simply having a desire does not constitute having a fundamental right. Rights are constructed by humans to make sense of laws of nature that a living things needs in order to survive. Nature constantly uses death to create new life. It is a beautiful circle that we are a part of.	Such a right would be internally inconsistent. Prey animals would then have a right to life which if policed by humans would deny a right of life to their natural predators which would then starve.	Animals have emotions, social systems, instincts, and intelligence. Humans should respect their existence. We have evolved and no longer need to prey on animals for our existence.
the only reason animals have not human-given rights is because we have chosen not to give rights to them. by their own existence, they have the right to life.	3_1.5.6.2.1.1. By their own existence, they have the right to life.	pro	Rights are a social construct for regulating the behaviour of humans within a society, and only function because humans are capable of conceptualizing the ideas of rights and responsibilities. Therefore, the reason that animals have not been given human rights may be because they are not applicable to most animals by definition.	Rights only exist in the minds of humans, so does the 'right to life'. Therefore, the claim contradicts itself.

animals do in fact have rights. many forms of cruelty are explicitly outlawed. one cannot, for instance, torture a dog for years in their basement. therefore the statement that animals do not have rights is fundamentally false.	3_1.5.7.	Animals do in fact have rights. Many forms of cruelty are explicitly outlawed. One cannot, for instance, torture a dog for years in their basement. Therefore the statement that animals do not have rights is fundamentally false.	pro	Humans have legal \(and ethical\) obligations with respect to animals, but that doesn't mean animals have reciprocal rights \(they cannot sue, be awarded damages, etc.\). Our obligations to animals exist as a matter of appropriate human behavior, not something that belongs to the animal.	The original statement this is responding to was indicating that animals "lack rights".  That is not false.  We do not live in a completely free society, and there are rules and laws which permit and prohibit certain behaviors.  Animals are lacking certain rights- in that humans are given rights which animals are not, such as a dog cannot walk unleashed in public areas.  Contrarily people lack certain rights which animals have, such as dogs being able to defecate in public.

our obligations to other humans exist solely as a matter of appropriate human behavior as well. and an impaired human might also not be able to "sue" or handle "money," and yet they would \(or would not\) have rights just like animals would \(or would not\) -- with perfect symmetry. any model of what "rights" are supposed to be can be shown to apply simultaneously to all animals, not just the human animal.	3_1.5.7.1.2. As a legal matter, animals do not have rights.

the claim that animals are not rational beings is debated. this book gives an overview of the different studies on animal rationality and interpretations of the term rationality [philpapers.org](https://philpapers.org/rec/hurra). since it is not clear that animals are not rational beings, you cannot just assume their actions lack moral content. and even if their actions lacked moral content to them, this might not be the case for us, as human beings interpreting their behaviour.	3_1.5.8.2. if life only produced suffering and negative experiences, this argument may hold water. however, life also produces joy and pleasure and enjoyable experiences. as such, according to [utilitarianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/utilitarianism) and similar ethical theories, our "job" or at least the most moral courses of action are to minimize suffering while maximizing pleasure and pleasant experiences.	3_1.5.8.6.4.3. As such, according to [Utilitarianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism) and similar ethical theories, our "job" or at least the most moral courses of action are to minimize suffering while maximizing pleasure and pleasant experiences.	pro	[Life creates both suffering and joy, but suffering is unavoidable.](https://www.kialo.com/eating-meat-is-wrong-1229/1229.0=1229.1+1229.21-1229.4083-1229.4289-1229.4314)
you cannot simply link another \(unsupported\) claim as "evidence". furthermore, even if this were 100% true, it would still be possible to attempt to create the most joy possible while creating the least suffering possible. neither of these claims rebuts the ultimate point, which is that even if perfection is impossible, improvement is not.	3_1.5.8.6.4.3.1.1. this claim is invoking moral skepticism - there is no objective basis for wrong and right. holding this position is extremely impractical as it permits all human behaviour and it follows that actions such as murder and rape- both observable in non-human life- are acceptable. in reality, this is not the case. human behaviour is governed by norms whose content is subjective but whose existence  is not. subjective though it may be, we accept that there are principles of right and wrong.	3_1.5.8.6.4.4.	This claim is invoking moral skepticism - there is no objective basis for wrong and right. Holding this position is extremely impractical as it permits all human behaviour and it follows that actions such as murder and rape- both observable in non-human life- are acceptable. In reality, this is not the case. Human behaviour is governed by norms whose content is subjective but whose existence  is not. Subjective though it may be, we accept that there are principles of right and wrong.	pro	The objective basis for wrong and right is provided by the system of morality used in the situation. The claim assumes that there is an objective right and wrong, which is ex definitio contradictory.	This claim inaccurately describes its parent. The parent claim is questioning the objectivity of ITS parent, and questioning the authority of the claimant to rule on the morality of participating in the circle of life by eating meat. The claimant argues that it is in fact cynical to pass judgment on the natural circle of life and those who participate in it. The claimant argues that it is impossible, and in fact immoral, for humans to pass judgment on life itself.	The norm for human behavior is not to extend all human rights to all animal life.

speciesism is the ideology that one species is 'better than' another simply because they view their species specific abilities as inherently more valueable than that of another species. many humans view cognition as the valuable human attribute that raises the value of our species above that of other animals, however, each animal contributes to the health and well-being of the planet in their own unique way, and it is impossible to categorize one characteristic as more valuable than the next.	3_1.5.10.7.	Speciesism is the ideology that one species is 'better than' another simply because they view their species specific abilities as inherently more valueable than that of another species. Many humans view cognition as the valuable human attribute that raises the value of our species above that of other animals, however, each animal contributes to the health and well-being of the planet in their own unique way, and it is impossible to categorize one characteristic as more valuable than the next.	pro

For any supposed capacity that humans possess and animals lack, and in virtue of which humans but not animals are taken to have rights, some humans will lack that capacity and some animals may possess that capacity. For instance, humans generally have the ability to reason, while most animals lack this capacity. But this cannot be the basis on which humans have and animals lack rights, because certain humans, including young infants, lack the ability to reason and certain animals may have it. This argument applies to human food production in general, but only to a small degree to meat. Compared to other food categories the share of the meat production lost during growth, harvesting, processing distribution and consumption [is actually lower](http://www.fao.org/docrep/014/mb060e/mb060e02.pdf).	Experts estimate that globally almost [12 billion animals'](http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/mar/19/meat-dairy-waste) lives are lost each year due to household food wastage. And [one third](http://www.fao.org/docrep/014/mb060e/mb060e02.pdf) of the edible parts of all food produced is lost/wasted globally. This equals about 1.3 billion tons of food per year. An extraordinary amount of living creatures born to be wasted.	Some predators do. It is known as [surplus killing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surplus_killing), in which preditors kill more prey than they can immediately eat and then cache or abandon the remainder.

\(over\)use of artificial \(or supplementary\) hormones negatively affects both the health of the animals and the consumer.	3_1.5.14.1.5.1.2.	\(Over\)use of artificial \(or supplementary\) hormones negatively affects both the health of the animals and the consumer.	pro	
many naturally occuring ecosystems are under a threat because of factory farming.	3_1.5.14.1.5.1.3.	Many naturally occuring ecosystems are under a threat because of factory farming.	pro	
it is not just that humans keep animals for slaughtering, but that they produce animals for the specific purpose of slaughtering and eating them. without the meat industry, these animals would not need to be bred in such numbers and less animals would be killed.	3_1.5.14.1.6.	It is not just that humans keep animals for slaughtering, but that they produce animals for the specific purpose of slaughtering and eating them. Without the meat industry, these animals would not need to be bred in such numbers and less animals would be killed.	pro	
your argument boils down to the claim that domesticated animals are better off than wild animals, with the counterfactual choice of the latter as a rhetorical tool. even if we accepted your claim that wild animals have "worse" lives, if would not logically mean that the unneccesary suffering  of animals raised for food could be justified \(similar faulty reasoning would be to claim that the poor in the us are better off than people in 3rd world slums and so they need no sympathy\)	3_1.5.14.1.7.1. not keeping an animal at all is therefore even "more humane" compared to both of these options. we should therefore, as intelligent beings, choose the best option possible and not keep animals at all, since we don`t need to do so.	3_1.5.14.1.10. We should therefore, as intelligent beings, choose the best option possible and not keep animals at all, since we don`t need to do so.	pro	
beeing kept in narrow spaces and very likely has a negative utilitarian value. the utilitarian value of nonexistence is neutral. since the animals we eat exist specifically for this purpose, not eating meat would lead to a neutral utilitarian value instead of a negative value.	3_1.5.14.4.	Beeing kept in narrow spaces and very likely has a negative utilitarian value. The utilitarian value of nonexistence is neutral. Since the animals we eat exist specifically for this purpose, not eating meat would lead to a neutral utilitarian value instead of a negative value.	pro	
life has a high amount of value in utilitarian terms because prematurely dying means not being able to experience the positive emotions you would otherwise. the prematurely short lives of animals raised just to maturity for meat is probably a larger utility loss than how they end up dying.	3_1.5.14.5.	Life has a high amount of value in utilitarian terms because prematurely dying means not being able to experience the positive emotions you would otherwise. The prematurely short lives of animals raised just to maturity for meat is probably a larger utility loss than how they end up dying.	pro	In utilitarian terms, ten animals that live for one year each in succession, and one animal that lives for ten years, if they experience the same utility, have the same moral value. Hence, there is no lost utility when meat animals die "prematurely" as long as the population does not shrink.
utilitarianism is not the most valid measure of moral value. often, principles such as "killing is wrong" are considered to be a moral law despite the fact that this may lead to higher level of happiness.	3_1.5.14.6.	Utilitarianism is not the most valid measure of moral value. Often, principles such as "killing is wrong" are considered to be a moral law despite the fact that this may lead to higher level of happiness.	pro	It can only be said that there is a more or less valid measure of moral value if there is a True \(objective\) Morality to be closer to or further from. If there is such a True Morality, it wouldn't be affected by what humans thought, because anyone who disagrees is objectively wrong. Hence, the fact that people often consider deontological principles to be valid moral rules cannot indicate that utilitarianism is a less valid measure of moral value than others.
historically, there have been times when certain categories of humans did not ‘have rights.’ many of those rights were denied due to a supposed ‘inferiority’ to groups in power, who possessed ‘rights.’ in some cases, those humans were born explicitly for exploitation. we now regognize how wrong those policies are and have been working past the problematic moral dilemmas and inequities these policies caused. it’s a moral imperative that we do the same with other species.	3_1.5.15.	Historically, there have been times when certain categories of humans did not ‘have rights.’ Many of those rights were denied due to a supposed ‘inferiority’ to groups in power, who possessed ‘rights.’ In some cases, those humans were born explicitly for exploitation. We now regognize how wrong those policies are and have been working past the problematic moral dilemmas and inequities these policies caused. It’s a moral imperative that we do the same with other species.	pro	This is a mischaracterisation of the history of philosophy; the understanding of fundamental or natural rights that we are referring to when we talk about rights in a modern context has been connected with a belief that all humans have the same rights since [the concept began](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_and_legal_rights#Ancient) with the Stoics.	While that might be the case within humanity as a group one can't apply the same standards for a different species entirely.
rights are inalienable and "endowed by our creator". they are not given just by law which why it is morally defensible to challenge laws that attempt to deny rights. even though current law does not give rights to animals, it does not mean that animals do not have them under the principles through which the concept of rights was created.	3_1.5.16.
