eating meat is linked to increased risks for certain types of cancer.	3_1.10.5.	Eating meat is linked to increased risks for certain types of cancer.	pro	Studies have linked heme iron found in red meat with an increased risk of colon and rectal [cancer](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10582688). Vegetarian sources of iron like leafy greens and beans contain [non-heme iron](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/nih_dietary_supplement_fact_sheet_on_iron.pdf).	Those who eat meat are far more likely to contract cancer than those following a [vegetarian](http://time.com/9463/7-reasons-vegetarians-live-longer/) diet.	[USDA researchers](https://www.peta.org/living/food/meat-contamination/) have found that eating two ounces of chicken per day \(the equivalent of a third to a half of a boneless breast\) exposes a consumer to 3 - 5 micrograms of the most carcinogenic form of arsenic, which can dramatically increase cancer risk.	Eating meat, particularly processed meats and bacon, has been recognized by the World Health Organization to be [carcinogenic](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24148709).	Recent research implies that cancer is a metabolic decrease, which in part forms the basis of the ketogenic diet \(eating meat and good fat\). [Cancer is a metabolic disease](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3941741/)	Most dietary cancers come from plants: PAHs from carbs; acrylamide from carbs; acetaldehyde from ferments like alcohol, soy sauce, and overripe fruit; aflatoxin from wheat fungus; nitrites from parsleys.	Studies done on negative health consequences of meat consumption are done in high carbohydrate diets. Carbohydrates are closer linked with cancer than meat consumption. [Starving cancer: Dominic D'Agostino at TEDxTampaBay](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3fM9o72ykww)
those who eat meat are far more likely to contract cancer than those following a [vegetarian](http://time.com/9463/7-reasons-vegetarians-live-longer/) diet.	3_1.10.5.2.	Those who eat meat are far more likely to contract cancer than those following a [vegetarian](http://time.com/9463/7-reasons-vegetarians-live-longer/) diet.	pro	
[usda researchers](https://www.peta.org/living/food/meat-contamination/) have found that eating two ounces of chicken per day \(the equivalent of a third to a half of a boneless breast\) exposes a consumer to 3 - 5 micrograms of the most carcinogenic form of arsenic, which can dramatically increase cancer risk.	3_1.10.5.3.	[USDA researchers](https://www.peta.org/living/food/meat-contamination/) have found that eating two ounces of chicken per day \(the equivalent of a third to a half of a boneless breast\) exposes a consumer to 3 - 5 micrograms of the most carcinogenic form of arsenic, which can dramatically increase cancer risk.	pro	There is no direct reference to the study here. Severe confounding or methodological challenges is possible.
eating meat, particularly processed meats and bacon, has been recognized by the world health organization to be [carcinogenic](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24148709).	3_1.10.5.4.	Eating meat, particularly processed meats and bacon, has been recognized by the World Health Organization to be [carcinogenic](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24148709).	pro	The carcinogens in processed meats come from heat and vegetal and mineral nitrites, not flesh.  The same carcinogens are present in potato chips, heated oils, prunes, and carrots.
the farming of meat can fuel the spread of disease and ingestion of drugs that may pose significant risks to human health.	3_1.10.6.	The farming of meat can fuel the spread of disease and ingestion of drugs that may pose significant risks to human health.	pro	Consuming meat from organic livestock farming could help to mitigate these risks.	Meat from factory farming contains a number of [growth hormones](https://www.organicconsumers.org/scientific/growth-hormones-fed-beef-cattle-damage-human-health) that are detrimental to our health.	Antibiotic use in animals farmed for meat can have harmful effects for human health.	[Diseases](http://theweek.com/articles/457135/5-modern-diseases-grown-by-factory-farming) such as BSE, MRSA or [bird flu](http://ecohearth.com/eco-zine/food-and-garden/865-swine-flu-bird-flu-and-bse-three-legacies-of-factory-farming-.html) are connected to intensive livestock farming conditions.	This is only true of CAFO or Industrial meat production.  Organic silvopasture, permacultural, and organic intensive grazing meat production do not create the same health risks. They do not use antibiotics and animal waste doesn't build up. It is, instead, immediately turned into fertilizer. Animals are kept away from areas of the pasture long enough for the waste to be incorporated into the soil and for the plants to recover.	[Animals cause vegetarian foods to get contaminated, which leads to food-borne illness. Eating meat increases the capabilities of animal products \(such as manure\) to contaminate crops \(such as using manure for fertilizer or wastewater for irrigation\).](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4265071/)This could lead to people who do not eat meat \(such as vegetarians\) to be affected \(i.e. sick\) by it, even though they do not contribute to the problem.
meat from factory farming contains a number of [growth hormones](https://www.organicconsumers.org/scientific/growth-hormones-fed-beef-cattle-damage-human-health) that are detrimental to our health.	3_1.10.6.2.	Meat from factory farming contains a number of [growth hormones](https://www.organicconsumers.org/scientific/growth-hormones-fed-beef-cattle-damage-human-health) that are detrimental to our health.	pro	[Chicken](http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/2812/chickens-do-not-receive-growth-hormones-so-why-all-the-confusion/) meat contains no growth hormones.
antibiotic use in animals farmed for meat can have harmful effects for human health.	3_1.10.6.3.	Antibiotic use in animals farmed for meat can have harmful effects for human health.	pro	75% of the antibiotics used on livestock are not absorbed by the animals and are instead excreted in their faeces, posing a [serious risk](http://www.worldwatch.org/global-meat-production-and-consumption-continue-rise-1) to public health.	[Studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4638249/)(Antibiotics are administered to animals in feed to marginally improve growth rates and to prevent infections, a practice projected to increase dramatically worldwide over the next 15 years. There is growing evidence that antibiotic resistance in humans is promoted by the widespread use of nontherapeutic antibiotics in animals. Resistant bacteria are transmitted to humans through direct contact with animals, by exposure to animal manure, through consumption of undercooked meat, and through contact with uncooked meat or surfaces meat has touched.) suggest that antibiotic resistance in humans may be encouraged by the widespread use of nontherapeutic antibiotics in animals.

the human body does not require consumption of animal protein.	3_1.10.7.3.	The human body does not require consumption of animal protein.	pro	All the high-quality amino acid [proteins](http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2016/05/19/478645426/humans-are-meathooked-but-not-designed-for-meat-eating) we require are readily available in plants such as buckwheat, quinoa and potatoes.	According to the [American Dietetic Association](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/american_dietetic_association_vegetarian_position.pdf) a vegetarian diet can meet protein requirements, provide all the essential amino-acids, necessary vitamins, fats and minerals.	There are enough [non-animal protein](http://www.health.com/health/gallery/0,,20718479,00.html) sources humans can consume.	Just because the human body can live without eating meat doesn't rationalize living without it, nor does it justify that something is unhealthy.	Eating meat or being able to live optimally without it or on alternative diets has been shown to be coded at a genetic level and this varies from one human to another. It is not always a simple moral or lifestyle choice.

food conversion makes loss of valuable protein. every animal used for meat needs a larger amount of \(plant based\) protein in their food than the amount of protein it produces. to grow 1 \(eatable\) kg in meat cow must eat somewhere between [25kgs](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s014102290100504x) and [35kgs](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/s0924224418308409) plant based feed. although not all of that food is usable for human consumption a lot of it is. this is a terrible loss of valuable nutrients.	3_1.10.7.5.4.	Food conversion makes loss of valuable protein. Every animal used for meat needs a larger amount of \(plant based\) protein in their food than the amount of protein it produces. To grow 1 \(eatable\) kg in meat cow must eat somewhere between [25kgs](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S014102290100504X) and [35kgs](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0924224418308409) plant based feed. Although not all of that food is usable for human consumption a lot of it is. This is a terrible loss of valuable nutrients.	pro	
vegetarians/vegans generally consume a diet consisting of [less](http://www.livestrong.com/article/481795-the-statistics-of-vegetarians-vs-meat-eaters/) saturated fat and cholesterol than the average meat eater.	3_1.10.7.6.	Vegetarians/vegans generally consume a diet consisting of [less](http://www.livestrong.com/article/481795-the-statistics-of-vegetarians-vs-meat-eaters/) saturated fat and cholesterol than the average meat eater.	pro	There is next to [no scientific evidence](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhzV-J1h0do#action=share) that a high-fat diet leads to a high cholesterol level; in fact, a high-fat diet turns out to be healthy in many ways.	[A high cholesterol level](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhzV-J1h0do#action=share) has not been finally determined to be the cause of coronary heart diseases; there has merely been found a correlation. Latest research counters the assumption that a high cholesterol level is concerning.
a meatless diet helps build healthy bones because vegetarians absorb more calcium than meat eaters.	3_1.10.7.7.	A meatless diet helps build healthy bones because vegetarians absorb more calcium than meat eaters.	pro	There are many sources of healthy [vegetarian calcium](http://drlisawatson.com/40-vegan-calcium-sources) including tofu, dark leafy greens like kale, spinach, and collard greens, as well as fortified cereals.	A meatless diet does not guarantee a higher absorbtion of calcium, because vegetarians can also eat unhealthy food and maintain an unbalanced diet.	Meat has high renal acid levels which the body must neutralize by [leaching calcium](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/pcrm_protecting_your_bones.pdf) from the bones, which is then passed into urine and lost.

there are only rare cases of vitamin b12 deficiencies and mostly this is [no problem](https://www.drmcdougall.com/misc/2007nl/nov/b12.htm) or easy to fix.	3_1.10.7.9.2.5.	There are only rare cases of vitamin B12 deficiencies and mostly this is [no problem](https://www.drmcdougall.com/misc/2007nl/nov/b12.htm) or easy to fix.	pro	Vitamin B12 deficiency is not rare but extremely undiagnosed due to doctors not running serum tests routinely. The serum tests aren't quite accurate either and functional ranges vary between countries. There are more sensitive markers for B12 deficiency that are now available including methylmalonic acid \(MMA\), measured both in the serum or the urine...there’s another marker called holotranscobalamin II \(or holoTC\) mostly used in Europe but is way more accurate. [chriskresser.com](https://chriskresser.com/why-b12-deficiency-is-significantly-underdiagnosed/)

the typical diets of meat eaters have a lot of [evidence showing them to be harmful](http://www.whatthehealthfilm.com/facts/) and have a particularly strong association to diseases of affluence. for example, heart disease, which is caused by atherosclerosis, the build up of plaque in the arteries. there are more efficient and sustainable methods for putting nutrients into our body than eating meat. these include [synthesizing nutrients from chemicals](http://www.doctorsresearch.com/articles4.html), modifying existing foods to use [less resources](http://c4rice.irri.org/index.php/component/content/article/19-about/55-why-c4-rice) or [have more nutrients](https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2013/03/07/173611461/in-a-grain-of-golden-rice-a-world-of-controversy-over-gmo-foods), and [individually growing food](https://www.seeker.com/food-helmet-sustains-you-with-algae-1767693118.html). way out there is [people being genetically enhanced to become autotrophs](http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120906-will-humans-ever-photosynthesise).	3_1.10.7.25. meat-eaters suffer more frequently from various types of [food poisoning](http://www.celestialhealing.net/physicalveg3.htm) than vegetarians.	3_1.10.9.	Meat-eaters suffer more frequently from various types of [food poisoning](http://www.celestialhealing.net/physicalveg3.htm) than vegetarians.	pro	According to the US Department of Agriculture \(USDA\) 70% of food poisoning is caused by contaminated [animal flesh](http://www.earthsave.org/pdf/ofof2006.pdf).	The CDC \(Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\) published in a [report](http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/255645.php) that leafy green vegetables like lettuce or spinach are among the top sources of food poisoning.	Seedy vegetables \(tomatoes, zucchinis\) are responsible for more [Salmonella](http://www.medicaldaily.com/salmonella-food-poisoning-most-common-vegetables-not-meat-325070) infections than any kind of meat in the USA.	Food poisoning occurs in cases of poor preparation of food and poor food hygiene. There is nothing more inherently risky in eating meat than in eating vegetables.	In terms of severity \(hospitalizations and deaths\) vegetarian diets offer no significant advantage for avoiding food poisoning. Hospitalizations and deaths \([wwwnc.cdc.gov](https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/5/5/99-0502-t3)\) are mostly due to listeria, salmonella, and toxoplasma gondii. None of these have any particular vegetarian advantages.	The largest food poisoning disasters \(dwarfing all others\) are chemical contamination of grain products. For example the [Iraq poison grain disaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_Iraq_poison_grain_disaster) or this case of [toxic cooking oil in spain](https://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/aug/25/research.highereducation).

living without meat reduces [metabolic risk](http://care.diabetesjournals.org/content/34/5/1225.abstract) factors and thus reduces the likelihood of strokes, diabetes, and heart conditions.	3_1.10.10.	Living without meat reduces [metabolic risk](http://care.diabetesjournals.org/content/34/5/1225.abstract) factors and thus reduces the likelihood of strokes, diabetes, and heart conditions.	pro	A compound found in red meat, called [carnitine](http://www.prevention.com/health/health-concerns/carnitine-red-meat-linked-risk-heart-disease), has been found to cause atherosclerosis, the hardening or clogging of the arteries.	A peer-reviewed [2004 study](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/a_prospective_study_of_red_meat_consumption_and_type2_diabetes.pdf) from Harvard researchers found that eating meat increases the risk of getting type 2 diabetes in women.	Amy Keating, a dietitian from Consumer Reports, says, "Many people replace the meat with refined carbohydrates," \([Nov. 2017 Consumer Reports](https://www.consumerreports.org/healthy-eating/eat-smarter-eat-healthier-sugar-salt-fat-gluten/)\), and these types of vegetarians have an increased risk of heart disease by 32%.	Eating meat [has recently been linked with developing Type 2 diabetes.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3942738/)	Alternative factors, such as that vegetarians smoke less and have an overall [healthier lifestyle](http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2849819/Vegetarians-healthier-meat-eating-cousins-not-happy-prone-mental-health-issues.html), are strong alternative variables.	[Vegetarians](http://time.com/9463/7-reasons-vegetarians-live-longer/) have lower blood pressure, are less likely to be overweight, and have less chance of heart diseases.	A meatless diet helps prevent hypertension, and thus reduces the risk of [stroke](http://vegetarian.procon.org/sourcefiles/hypertension_and_blood_pressure_among_meat_eaters_fish_eaters_vegetarians_and_vegans_in_epic_oxford.pdf). comparing the lifestyle and diet of the inuit people to that of most meat consumers is a false equivalency. the source of their meat is vastly different from industrially produced meat found in grocery stores, and their daily lives are vastly different from the average meat consumer. even when adjusted by age, race, smoking, exercise, personal income, educational level, marital status, alcohol, and region, [studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/pmc4073139/) have shown that plant based diets lead to reduced health risks.	3_1.10.13.1.2.	Comparing the lifestyle and diet of the Inuit people to that of most meat consumers is a false equivalency. The source of their meat is vastly different from industrially produced meat found in grocery stores, and their daily lives are vastly different from the average meat consumer. Even when adjusted by age, race, smoking, exercise, personal income, educational level, marital status, alcohol, and region, [studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4073139/) have shown that plant based diets lead to reduced health risks.	pro	
the lifestyles of these groups are radically different from normal human populations in very many ways. the fact that they are healthy therefore does not prove that their consumption of meat does not harm them - it could simply be the case that the harm is offset by other aspects of their lifestyles.	3_1.10.13.2.	The lifestyles of these groups are radically different from normal human populations in very many ways. The fact that they are healthy therefore does not prove that their consumption of meat does not harm them - it could simply be the case that the harm is offset by other aspects of their lifestyles.	pro	There is no baseline for 'normal human populations' . Every established ethnic and regional group has adapted their diet to their environment and available resources. Changes to these diets result in negative health effects and so whilst eating meat does not confer any advantage, ceasing its consumption will inflict a negative effect on their health.	For the group tests to be valid, they should also be checked for malnutrition in general, and also be tested with vegan equivalent supplements that offer a similar dose of iron, protein and other nutrients that those groups' existing diets are lacking.

They benefit from both.
per pound, spirulina has over double the protein of chicken \([261g](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/foods/show/3306?man=&lfacet=&count=&max=&qlookup=&offset=&sort=&format=abridged&reportfmt=other&rptfrm=&ndbno=&nutrient1=&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=&totcount=&measureby=&qv=4.536&q6228=1&q6229=1&qv=1&q6228=1&q6229=1) vs [113g](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/foods/show/937?man=&lfacet=&count=&max=50&qlookup=chicken+meat+cooked&offset=&sort=default&format=abridged&reportfmt=other&rptfrm=&ndbno=&nutrient1=&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=&totcount=&measureby=&qv=4.536&q2228=1&q2229=1&qv=1&q2228=1&q2229=1)\)	3_1.10.16.1. healthy vegetarian foods [clean your teeth while you eat \(called "detergent foods" for that purpose\)](http://www.drhudis.com/blog/2016/08/detergent-foods-clean-your-teeth-while-you-eat).	3_1.10.16.2. vegetarian food is high in beneficial nutrients \(such as [vitamin k](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totcount=0&nutrient1=430&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g) and [magnesium](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totcount=0&nutrient1=304&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g)\) whereas meat is high in unhealthier ones \(such as calories and [cholesterol](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totcount=0&nutrient1=601&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g)\) when in excess	3_1.10.16.3.	Vegetarian food is high in beneficial nutrients \(such as [Vitamin K](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totCount=0&nutrient1=430&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g) and [magnesium](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totCount=0&nutrient1=304&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g)\) whereas meat is high in unhealthier ones \(such as calories and [cholesterol](https://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/nutrients/report/nutrientsfrm?max=25&offset=0&totCount=0&nutrient1=601&nutrient2=&nutrient3=&subset=0&sort=c&measureby=g)\) when in excess	pro	The Vitamin K2 \(more absorbable form\) amounts are the highest \(lb for lb\) in the vegan food natto \([over 1mg while the meat runner up is under 0.4mg](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/vitamin-k1-vs-k2)\).

meat is dangerous in that it increases the risk of injuries to those who eat meat.	3_1.10.17.	Meat is dangerous in that it increases the risk of injuries to those who eat meat.	pro	Ingesting "[bones can lead to intestinal perforation and peritonitis](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3856294/)"	[Beef jerky increases tooth pain and possibly triggers temporomandibular joint \(TMJ\)](http://diet.lovetoknow.com/why-does-beef-jerky-hurt-my-teeth)	[Meat trapped in-between teeth \(i.e. food impaction\) can be a reason for sore gums.](http://www.intelligentdental.com/2009/09/09/causes-of-sore-gums/)	[Grilled food usually is associated with meat \(burgers, hot dogs, steak...\). Wire brushes for cleaning a grill expose people to possibly ingesting the bristles and having emergency situations \(i.e. GI tract injuries\)](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6126a4.htm)	[Deboning fish by-mouth can lead to injuries such as nose bleeds, choking, and facial puncturing](http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/202360/help-ive-swallowed-a-fish-bone/).	Knives pose a danger to eaters from meats that require cutting before eating. In Spain, "[60,000 Spaniards end up in emergency rooms each year because of ham-cutting accidents](https://www.pri.org/stories/2012-08-23/dangerous-art-ham-cutting-spain)".	[People can chip their teeth from biting into bone.](https://www.injuryclaimcoach.com/questions/broken-tooth-biting-into-bone.html)	Some of these could occur while eating vegan foods too, such as cutting large and tough-skinned fruits and vegetables.	[Blenders used to make vegetarian foods \(such as smoothies\) cause emergency room visits](https://www.consumerreports.org/cro/news/2013/02/blender-injuries-stir-up-more-visits-to-the-emergency-room/index.htm).

assuming life long veganism and assuming it is less damaging to environment, comparisons need to be made between lifetime damage to environment on vegans vs omnivores, considering vegans would potentially have longer lives but less damaging time on earth.	3_1.10.18.1.	Assuming life long veganism and assuming it is less damaging to environment, comparisons need to be made between lifetime damage to environment on vegans vs omnivores, considering vegans would potentially have longer lives but less damaging time on earth.	pro	
according to [this study](https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/78/3/526s/4689992), life expectancy might be slightly greater \(3.6 yrs\) for long term vegetarians - around a 4.5% increase, assuming an average lifespan. this is probably not great enough to negate the environmental benefits; [this study](https://www.nature.com/articles/1602522) suggests at least 13% reduction of impact for vegetarians, or 28% for vegans.	3_1.10.18.2.	According to [this study](https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article/78/3/526S/4689992), life expectancy might be slightly greater \(3.6 yrs\) for long term vegetarians - around a 4.5% increase, assuming an average lifespan. This is probably not great enough to negate the environmental benefits; [this study](https://www.nature.com/articles/1602522) suggests at least 13% reduction of impact for vegetarians, or 28% for vegans.	pro	
[we are not meant to eat meat.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z3u7hxpom58) a lot of people have explained how we have not developed biologically to hunt, consume or digest meat, here is a 30 minute explanation from a former meat lover turned vegan. fridges should be gardens not morgues.	3_1.10.23.	[We are not meant to eat meat.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z3u7hXpOm58) A lot of people have explained how we have not developed biologically to hunt, consume or digest meat, here is a 30 minute explanation from a former meat lover turned vegan. Fridges should be gardens not morgues.	pro
